text: Patient: I’m doing a lot. Doctor: And, uh, that, we have to be really careful about because I don’t want that to ruin your quality of life. But, I think for the most part, it’s more just gut/GI-ish stuff. So, this lack of appetite, and some people might be, like, “Wow, my stomach actually, you know, doesn’t feel good.” To, “I’ve got diarrhea or nausea.” So, all of that could lead to dehydration. You know, like, we just have to be super on top of that. Patient: Sure. Doctor: To make sure you don’t fall off the grid. Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And it cannot substitute as a weight loss plan. Doctor: Let me just say it for the record. Patient: Well, yeah. We’re working on that part of it. Family Member: Yes. We are.

text: Patient: No. Well some swelling. (pause and ruffling sounds) Doctor: A little bit. No bumps at all up here. No pain, no itching. Patient: No. I noticed some weakness in my right leg. Doctor: They drew blood today. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Last week? Patient: Last week, yes, and my PSA jumped up tremendously. This is from last year. This is December and this is last week – up point five. Doctor: Blood count is good, tab - nothing dramatic – sporadic just below the normal range. So your kidney function goes up and down. So two months hundred at one point six, then it was repeated back down to one and then it was up at one point five. Where did you have your scan last week? Patient: In Hospital A in B___. I have the information and phone number. Doctor: So is G___ a new doctor for you or have you seen him for a while? Patient: No, that was only the second visit. And I saw him after, thoracic surgeon in Hospital B and spotted through tests, prostate cancer cells in my liver, and also on my lung Family Member: December. Patient: And that’s when he recommended I see an oncologist there. He teaches up here, too, so. He’s kind of the go-between. And he’s the one that said he’d work on the lung problem.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But, your earlier ones prior to July were sort of January/February time point. So, if I just take down the bone, you’ve had a variety of different reports, right so your January one was lots of different spots and then I think your July one we don’t have an official report but it didn’t seem to change much, you know, kind of different spots, but then on the CAT scan it only just showed one area because it was such a limited area that I would imagine that your bones still have multiple spots. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We know that your PSA hovers around the one twenty nine, one thirty mark. It’s kind of been staying there. It’s not five hundred but it’s not fifty, Patient: Right. Doctor: but it’s enough to say this might be the reason why, you know, you’re getting more tired and having some pain which may not be related to that. Now, your actual CAT scan reports are always a little inconsistent so that’s why I think it’s not confusing but challenging. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, your January/February scan had maybe something on your adrenal glands, maybe something in your liver, maybe some clumpy lymph nodes, and you’re like oh, okay. So, when I sent you over for like additional, you know, trials you had areas to measure outside your bone but then you kind of don’t. So, on your last CAT scan we couldn’t see anything where the liver was so that’s just not there, the lymph nodes kind of where the adrenal area was is enlarged so you don’t fit that. Oh, that’s wonderful. You made my life a living bleep when I was like oh, yay, but oh, yay, oh, yay, oh. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I’m thrilled that you don’t have the cancer that we say earlier that might have been from the pills you were on Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: but then I’m kind of stuck in terms of well, I’m not really sure if I know where you are right now in October. So, sometimes when I get a little bit stuck and I’m trying to well, there’s this and that, just stop. It doesn’t have to be a mystery because we can just do a full set. So, like you should get a bone scan because the last time was July and we’re in October. You’re in pain so maybe I got to look for new spots that we have to try to treat. That’s one. Then, you know, a bone scan and then a CAT scan, but one that also includes the chest to make sure I’m not missing anything up higher that maybe is causing some of the lower pain. So, I think from here to here and your bone scan we can get that in a few days.

text: Patient: The body reacts- Family Member: Why would it do that? Doctor: Uh, because basically the medicine is, uh, a protein your body makes and just fools the brain into thinking that there’s too much testosterone, uh, and sort of tells the testicles, “Stop making testosterone.” But that which is there gets released. Family Member: Ahhh. Doctor: And so you just get a surge. And so, Family Member: Ahh. Patient: So, you’re, you’re trying to drive the level, the level down so when the surge happens, it doesn’t peak, or it peaks as low as it - Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yay. text: Patient: I’ve been praying that… Doctor: We removed it and the fact that we removed it may minimize the reoccurrence. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So we’ll see. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
